prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: CO(1-0) flux derived from IRAM 30m observations by Welch et al (2010) with a 21" HPBW. Assuming a standard Jy/K conversion factor of 6.5, the integrated flux for the IRAM observations would be ~ 100 Jy km/s for a FWHM of 150 km/s To obtain a linear resolution of ~70pc at the distance of NGC1052, we need an angular resolution of 0.8". To obtain the required sensitivity in the CO(1-0) line, for a 5 sigma detection, we estimate the required RMS for a 10km/s spectral resolution to be: 100 Jy km/s / 150 km/s * 5 km/s * (0.8" / 21") **2 / 5 (sigma) ~ 2.3 mJy Since we intend to bin the data in velocity, we choose the spectral set-up for the spw with the CO(1-0) line in to be the coarsest FDM mode. Three additional spectral windows have been added to each set-up for continuum observations (TDM mode). They have been distributed to cover most of the bandwidth on both sidebands that is not observed by the FDM spectral window used to map the CO(1-0) emission. We are not requesting any additional time to detect the continuum of these sources, so we will only use the continuum information to obtain upper limits (in case of non-detections) or measurements in case of detections (for NGC 1052, the nuclear compact source is ~0.6 Jy at 3mm, so we should be able to detect it easily with 6 GHz of bandwidth). We need to recover angular scales up to 18". According to the OT, for these scales and angular resolution of 0.8", no ACA observations are required

CO(1-0) flux derived from IRAM 30m observations by Combes et al (2007) with a 21" HPBW. Assuming a standard Jy/K conversion factor of 6.5, the integrated flux for the IRAM observations would be ~ 10.4 Jy km/s for a FWHM of 180 km/s Since the expected size of the CO distribution in this object is ~11", an additional factor of 4 due to beam dilution must be taken into account, resulting in an integrated flux of 41.6 Jy km/s for a 11" beam To obtain a linear resolution of ~70pc at the distance of NGC3156, we need an angular resolution of 1". To obtain the required sensitivity in the CO(1-0) line, for a 5 sigma detection, we estimate the required RMS for a 5km/s spectral resolution to be: 42 Jy km/s / 180 km/s * 5 km/s * (1" / 11") **2 / 5 (sigma) ~ 2 mJy Since we intend to bin the data in velocity, we choose the spectral set-up for the spw with the CO(1-0) line in to be the coarsest FDM mode. Three additional spectral windows have been added to each set-up for continuum observations (TDM mode). They have been distributed to cover most of the bandwidth on both sidebands that is not observed by the FDM spectral window used to map the CO(1-0) emission. We are not requesting any additional time to detect the continuum of these sources, so we will only use the continuum information to obtain upper limits (in case of non-detections) or measurements in case of detections. We need to recover angular scales up to 11". According to the OT, for these scales and angular resolution of 1", no ACA observations are required

CO(1-0) flux derived from IRAM 30m observations by Welch et al (2010) with a 21" HPBW. Assuming a standard Jy/K conversion factor of 6.5, the integrated flux for the IRAM observations would be ~ 9.75 Jy km/s for a FWHM of 500 km/s Since the expected size of the CO distribution in this object is ~12", an additional factor of 4 due to beam dilution must be taken into account, resulting in an integrated flux of 39 Jy km/s for a 12" beam To obtain a linear resolution of ~70pc at the distance of NGC3818, we need an angular resolution of 0.8". To obtain the required sensitivity in the CO(1-0) line, for a 5 sigma detection, we estimate the required RMS for a 10km/s spectral resolution to be: 39 Jy km/s / 500 km/s * 10 km/s * (1" / 12") **2 / 5 (sigma) ~ 1.3 mJy Since we intend to bin the data in velocity, we choose the spectral set-up for the spw with the CO(1-0) line in to be the coarsest FDM mode. Three additional spectral windows have been added to each set-up for continuum observations (TDM mode). They have been distributed to cover most of the bandwidth on both sidebands that is not observed by the FDM spectral window used to map the CO(1-0) emission. We are not requesting any additional time to detect the continuum of these sources, so we will only use the continuum information to obtain upper limits (in case of non-detections) or measurements in case of detections. We need to recover angular scales up to 12". According to the OT, for these scales and angular resolution of 0.8", no ACA observations are required

CO(1-0) flux derived from NRO 45m observations by Sofue et al (1993) with a 16" HPBW. Assuming a standard Jy/K conversion factor of 3, the integrated flux for the NRO observations would be ~ 13 Jy km/s for a FWHM of 100 km/s Since the expected size of the CO distribution in this object is ~40", we assume a flat flux distribution outside the area mapped by the 45m telescope To obtain a linear resolution of ~70pc at the distance of NGC4697, we need an angular resolution of 1". To obtain the required sensitivity in the CO(1-0) line, for a 5 sigma detection, we estimate the required RMS for a 10km/s spectral resolution to be: 13 Jy km/s / 100 km/s * 10 km/s * (1" / 16") **2 / 5 (sigma) ~ 2 mJy Since we intend to bin the data in velocity, we choose the spectral set-up for the spw with the CO(1-0) line in to be the coarsest FDM mode. Three additional spectral windows have been added to each set-up for continuum observations (TDM mode). They have been distributed to cover most of the bandwidth on both sidebands that is not observed by the FDM spectral window used to map the CO(1-0) emission. We are not requesting any additional time to detect the continuum of these sources, so we will only use the continuum information to obtain upper limits (in case of non-detections) or measurements in case of detections. We need to recover angular scales up to 43". According to the OT, for these scales and angular resolution of 1", additional ACA observations are required

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: We propose CO(1-0) mapping observations of 4 nearby elliptical galaxies. The galaxies were selected for their proximity, and for evidence of the presence of molecular gas in their central regions. With spatial resolutions of ~1", we will be able to resolve local structures within the molecular gas at scales comparable to thise of large galactic giant molecular clouds. Furthermore, we intend to carry out a detailed study of the local and large scale dynamics of any molecular gas present in these objects. To do this, we intend to recover the CO(1-0) emission up to scales comparable to ~1/10 of their optical major axes. This will require the combined use of the 12m array and the ACA for some of the objects in the sample. The data obtained in these observations will be used to study in unprecedented detail the mechanisms of star formation/inhibition in elliptical galaxies, origi n of the molecular gas in these objects, and try to detect organized local molecular structures in them (GMCs, spiral arms, wisps, etc). ALMA Cycle 2 is ideally suited for these observations, providing both the required sensitivity and high-quality imaging for this project.

prp:CoInvestigator.prp:organisation: ALMA Project Office, National Astronomical Observatory of Japan
Dept of Physics & Astronomy, McMaster University
